synthesis_title: Privacy-Preserving Identity Graph for Advertiser Targeting: Research Synthesis

source_article.title: Bridging privacy-preserving approaches: a formal comparison of k-automorphism, k-isomorphism, and k-symmetry
source_article.institution: University of Hradec Kralove, Czech Republic

k-automorphism.definition: A graph G is k-automorphic if for every node v, there exist at least k-1 other nodes that occupy structurally identical positions via automorphism permutations
k-automorphism.foundational_paper: Zou et al. (2009) - K-Automorphism: A General Framework for Privacy Preserving Network Publication (VLDB)
k-automorphism.relevance_to_identity_graph: Defines the mathematical framework for making identity graph nodes structurally indistinguishable — the privacy guarantee you apply before sharing behavioral graph data with advertisers

k-symmetry.definition: A graph is k-symmetric if every orbit (equivalence class under automorphism) contains at least k nodes
k-symmetry.foundational_paper: Wu et al. (2010) - K-Symmetry Model for Identity Anonymization in Social Networks
k-symmetry.relevance_to_identity_graph: EQUIVALENT to k-automorphism (proven by Medkova 2025). Simpler to implement. Use orbit-based grouping to create anonymized audience segments where no individual is structurally unique

k-isomorphism.definition: An anonymized graph built from k structurally identical (isomorphic) disconnected subgraphs
k-isomorphism.foundational_paper: Cheng et al. (2010) - K-Isomorphism: Privacy Preserving Network Publication Against Structural Attacks
k-isomorphism.relevance_to_identity_graph: Creates k identical copies of the graph structure. Strongest guarantee but highest information loss. Use for maximum-privacy data clean rooms

key_insight_from_article: k-automorphism and k-symmetry are formally equivalent. k-isomorphism is related but distinct due to connectivity requirements. For practical identity graph systems, k-symmetry is the simplest to implement while providing the same guarantee as k-automorphism.

attack_this_defends_against.attack_description: A purely structural, passive attack that re-identifies individuals in anonymized social network graphs by matching graph topology patterns against auxiliary data. Demonstrated 33% re-identification on Twitter/Flickr with only 12% error rate.
attack_this_defends_against.why_it_matters: If you share behavioral graph data with advertisers (even 'anonymized'), this attack can re-identify individual users from connection patterns alone. The k-anonymity techniques from the article are specifically designed to prevent this.

graph_types_needed.identity_resolution_graph: Bipartite graph: identifiers (cookies, device IDs, emails, phone hashes) as nodes, edges link identifiers belonging to same person. Use probabilistic record linkage (Fellegi-Sunter) or GNN-based matching.
graph_types_needed.behavioral_graph: User-touchpoint graph: users connected to events (site visits, purchases, ad views). Edges weighted by recency/frequency. Use for behavioral segmentation.
graph_types_needed.similarity_graph: Users as nodes, edges weighted by behavioral similarity. Use community detection (Louvain, Leiden) for lookalike audience modeling.
graph_types_needed.interest_intent_graph: Users connected to interest categories inferred from browsing/purchase/content patterns. Use heterogeneous graph transformers for multi-modal signal fusion.
